Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Extremal Combinatorics: Methods, Problems, and Challenges
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project considers a variety of problems related to Szemerédi's regularity method and Ramsey theory. In tackling these problems, the PI will use a range of combinatorial methods that have recently led to substantial progress on related problems. Examples include probabilistic methods, density increment arguments, transference arguments, analytic tools, and embedding techniques. The first area in this project concerns Szemerédi's regularity method. Within this area, one of the main goals of the project is to obtain new bounds on the triangle removal lemma and its various extensions and variants. The triangle removal lemma states that any graph with a subcubic number of triangles can be made triangle-free by removing a subquadratic number of edges. Another major goal of the project is to further push the regularity method to sparse graphs and other combinatorial structures, and to obtain new applications. Specific problems include optimizing the pseudorandomness conditions needed to obtain sparse counting lemmas, proving analogous sparse regularity results in other combinatorial structures such as cubes, and providing new applications in number theory and discrete geometry such as extensions of the Green-Tao theorem on long arithmetic progressions in the primes. The second area in this project is estimating Ramsey numbers. The PI will work on proving new bounds for classical (complete) graph and hypergraph Ramsey numbers, and to prove linear bounds for Ramsey numbers of sparse graphs.

This project studies fundamental problems in combinatorics related to the structure of large networks. Examples of large networks include the Internet, Facebook, the brain, imperfect crystals, and designed chips. The structure of these networks can be critical in understanding how the networks function. Previous work has shown that the subjects under study in this project have a wide range of applications. Furthermore, this work has led to the development of powerful methods that have been used in many branches of mathematics and computer science. For example, previous progress on estimating Ramsey numbers led to the development of probabilistic techniques that have had a tremendous influence on computer science, such as in the design of randomized algorithms. It is expected that further work on these problems will lead to new methods and applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project led to a deeper understanding of regularity methods and its applications in combinatorics, number theory, and computer science. These include fast algorithms for counting small subgraphs in graphs and property testing in networks and in arithmetic settings, and the solution of several major open problems in the area.

Ramsey theory contains many deep results in mathematics that roughly say that any sufficiently large enough structure, no matter how disordered, must contain a nice well-organized substructure. One of the main questions in Ramsey theory is to estimate the growth of Ramsey numbers, which is how large the structure needs to be to guarantee a well-organized substructure. This grant led to new bounds for various Ramsey numbers of interest and shed important light on this major combinatorial problem.

Intellectual Merit. This completed grant studied and solved some fundamental problems in combinatorics. These problems had already been shown to have wide range of applications to number theory, computer science, and discrete and computational geometry.  Furthermore, this work has led to the development of powerful methods, including the probabilistic, algebraic, and regularity methods, which have diverse applications in mathematics and computer science. For example, previous progress on estimating Ramsey numbers led to the development of powerful probabilsitic technqieus, which are now at the heart of the design of randomized algorithms and the use of probability in computational complexity theory. It is expected that the progress made on this project will lead to further connections, applications, and methods beyond those already found during the project.

Broader Impact. In addition to research, the PI has worked to advance mathematics through training and education. The PI developed new undergraduate and graduate level courses that has broadened the knowledge of the important ideas and techniques used in combinatorics, and has publicly shared these materials online. The PI has advised many PhD students (five PhD students finished durig the course of the grant), and most have continued to strong research careers. The PI has also closely worked with researchers in other fields, most notably computer science. The PI has promoted the research to wide audiences through public lectures and distinguished lecture series, including those at Harvard, Stanford, IAS, and ETH, as well as many talks directly at levels from middle school students through advanced researchers.
